Let $U_i \sim  N_p(\mu_i, \Sigma ), \quad i=1,\ldots, k$ be independent
$p$-dimensional random variables, which are . Let
$S= \sum_{i=1}^k U_i {U_i}^T$. Let $M$ be the $k\times p$ matrix with
$\mu_1, \ldots, \mu_k$ as rows. Then the joint distribution of the
elements of $S$ is said to be a *Wishart distribution on* $k$ *of
freedom* , and is denoted by $W_p(k, \Sigma, M)$. If $M=0$, the
distribution is said to be *central* and is denoted by $W_p(k, \Sigma)$.
The Wishart distribution is a multivariate generalization of the
$\chi^2$ distribution.

$W_p$ has a density function when $k \geq p$.
